title: [GitHub Extension] Unsanitised HTML leading to XSS on GitHub.com

profile.name: Algolia
profile.about: Hosted search API that delivers instant and relevant results from the first keystroke

vulnerability_information: Hi, I noticed that certain HTML is unsanitised by the Awesome Autocomplete for GitHub extension, leading to a case of XSS on the GitHub website. Please note that I **do not have ownership nor affiliation** with the repository and user names in this report, nor the final JavaScript alert dialog. # Proof of Concept I have tested the following Proof of Concept demonstrations with the following conditions: ### Extension * Latest version of the Awesome Autocomplete extension ### Operating Systems * macOS Sierra 10.12.4 * Windows 7 x64 ### Browsers * Google Chrome 57.0.2987.133 (latest) * Safari 10.1 (latest) ## Unsanitised HTML Please follow the below steps to demonstrate the presence of an unsanitised HTML issue. 1. Search for `'">` element and requests to "x" on GitHub.com The following images demonstrate that a broken `` element was created in the context of GitHub.com by the Algolia extension: {F175284} {F175283} ## XSS on GitHub Please follow the below steps to demonstrate the presence of a full XSS issue. 1. Search for `a'">
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,

I noticed that certain HTML is unsanitised by the Awesome Autocomplete for GitHub extension, leading to a case of XSS on the GitHub website.

Please note that I do not have ownership nor affiliation with the repository and user names in this report, nor the final JavaScript alert dialog.

Proof of Concept

I have tested the following Proof of Concept demonstrations with the following conditions:

Extension

  • Latest version of the Awesome Autocomplete extension

Operating Systems

  • macOS Sierra 10.12.4
  • Windows 7 x64

Browsers

  • Google Chrome 57.0.2987.133 (latest)
  • Safari 10.1 (latest)

Unsanitised HTML

Please follow the below steps to demonstrate the presence of an unsanitised HTML issue.

  1. Search for '"><img src=x onerror= on GitHub.com
  2. Note the broken <img> element and requests to "x" on GitHub.com

The following images demonstrate that a broken <img> element was created in the context of GitHub.com by the Algolia extension:

XSS on GitHub

Please follow the below steps to demonstrate the presence of a full XSS issue.

  1. Search for a'"><h1 on GitHub.com
  2. Because of a specific repository name being loaded, a JavaScript alert dialog will appear:

As noted above, I am currently attempting to reproduce this vulnerability using my own repositories and JavaScript code (e.g. document.domain rather than "1337").

Please let me know if you require any additional information regarding these vulnerabilities.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Quick update – was looking into the source of where the "1337" originates and noted that the XSS cannot be reproduced on the **github.algolia.com** marketing site due to HTML escaping. {F175290} From the above image, I believe that the following string will lead to XSS in the context of GitHub.com: ``` ">

A

``` EDIT: Looks like XSS may also be possible through Issue Names – just waiting for indexing so that my newly created issue(s) appear. {F175292}
activities.markdown_message:
Quick update – was looking into the source of where the "1337" originates and noted that the XSS cannot be reproduced on the github.algolia.com marketing site due to HTML escaping.

From the above image, I believe that the following string will lead to XSS in the context of GitHub.com:

"><script>alert(1)</script><h1>A</h1>

EDIT: Looks like XSS may also be possible through Issue Names – just waiting for indexing so that my newly created issue(s) appear.

activities.message:
Confirming additional vector of XSS via issue details – please find below an additional Proof of Concept screenshot along with the following steps: {F175308} 1. Create a new repository, and a new issue within 2. Place the following in the issue title and description: `">

A

` 3. Search for a single apostrophe (`'`) inside "this repository" and the XSS will execute.
activities.markdown_message:
Confirming additional vector of XSS via issue details – please find below an additional Proof of Concept screenshot along with the following steps:

  1. Create a new repository, and a new issue within
  2. Place the following in the issue title and description: "><script>alert("XSS on " + document.domain + ". Cookies: " + document.cookie)</script><h1>A</h1>
  3. Search for a single apostrophe (') inside "this repository" and the XSS will execute.

activities.message:
Hi @ysx,

thank you very much for this deep analysis. We've improved the sanitization feature & deployed it to production earlier today. Everything should be fine now :+1:
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @ysx,

thank you very much for this deep analysis. We've improved the sanitization feature & deployed it to production earlier today. Everything should be fine now :+1:

activities.message: Hi @redox, no problem – confirming the fix in prod!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @redox, no problem – confirming the fix in prod!

activities.message: Thanks for the bounty and resolution @adams! Would it be possible to publicly disclose this report please?
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the bounty and resolution @adams! Would it be possible to publicly disclose this report please?

summaries.content: In certain cases, HTML elements were unsanitised by the Awesome Autocomplete extension when presented in DOM, leading to XSS on the GitHub website. Thanks to the Algolia team for the swift resolution and fix.
summaries.content_html: In certain cases, HTML elements were unsanitised by the Awesome Autocomplete extension when presented in DOM, leading to XSS on the GitHub website. Thanks to the Algolia team for the swift resolution and fix.
